description: Fly around the world without leaving the ground! Our state of the art Boeing 737 flight simulator which is built into an actual aircraft nose. Realistic flight controls and visuals. Over 100,000 airports worldwide. Each session is good for up to 4 people for the same price. No previous flying experience is necessary. As real as it gets without flying a real plane! We are open 7 days a week, and conveniently located across from Toronto Pearson International Airport. Within a few minutes walk from all airport area hotels. Click or call to book your Airliner Adventure today!

reviews.title: Threshold Aviation B737 Sim - 3 hour package
text: After several years of flying a desktop and the PMDG B737 NG I booked the 3 hour package at Threshold Aviation; long story short, it exceeded my expectations and was well worth the visit!
Mickey is an excellent instructor who took the time to fill in the gaps and made sure I had time to experience several different approaches and flight configurations.

The session was long enough to start from cold & dark, fly an IFR plan from YYYZ down the ILS to KBOS, then final approach into Innsbruck, the checkerboard approach into Kai Tak, and finally the approach into St. Maarten.
The sim is built from an actual B737 cockpit and set's itself apart by using actual Boeing parts - no reproductions; and Threshold is continuing to make upgrades and improve the sim.

For those of you just interested in aviation, Threshold provides the chance to see what goes on behind the curtain.  And for those of you who fly sims as a hobby, this should most assuredly be a "bucket-list" experience.

reviews.title: It felt very realistic
text: Yes this is an actual 737 that has been turned into a simulator. This means that all the switches, controls, seats etc. are genuine 737 not a computer simulation. You look through the windows and the view is projected onto the walls surrounding the plane. Graphics probably could be a bit sharper or more detailed but they were quite good and responded as expected. I flew it into, among other places, Wiarton. There is a very large selection of airports to fly into. I am familiar with Wiarton airport from having flown my Cessna 172 there so I could judge the simulation and it is good. The one thing it does not have is motion of the plane but that is only found on the multi million $ simulators. The person who acted as our instructor was very good.

reviews.title: Learn all about those take-off noises
text: I'm not a pilot or an aviation geek, but I do have a powerful streak of "what do these buttons do?" technical curiosity, and Airliner Adventures fits into my personal "action movie" curriculum, alongside things like "operate a Caterpillar excavator."

I picked the simplest one-hour "scenic flight" package (C$129 plus HST) and was assigned "Mikey" as my instructor. The default experience is to take off from Toronto International Aiport (YYZ), fly through downtown Toronto and over Lake Ontario, then back. You will need to un-learn automobile reflexes, and will probably crash the first time, but your instructor can reset the approach.

Their "737NG" simulator, a combination of genuine Boeing parts and Canadian replicas, isn't atop a motion platform, but the panoramic view beyond the windows, sounds, and force feedback are thoroughly convincing. There's space behind the cockpit for spectators. The "Threshold Aviation" store is stocked with airliner replicas, mechanical flight computers and other pilot gear, aviation swag, and Toronto souvenirs. It's located in a strip mall just outside the airport (incidentally, beneath an approach path), so it's accessible on a long layover (a 2.2 km hike, if you tried such a thing).

Do: Make an appointment. Wear long pants -- twisting into the seat is a tight fit, and it's easy to scrape your shins on the center console. If you're a solo visitor, ask a staff member to take a photo. If you have nothing particular in mind before you start, ask about options and how long each will take (explain all the panels, full start-up checklist, flying, picking an interesting airport and weather conditions, etc.).
